text: I understand it was just all i could do at the time
i mean my lanparty nf4-ut expert mobo has raid aswell supported by the nf4 chip
ok well i need to be able to tell ubuntu that these two drives arent seperate drives and are in a stripe
not a mirror
I would have liked to do it in the install phase but seeing as i was pinched for time its gonna have to be post install :S
thats fine
the rate of transfere boost that this will give will make things better
Ok well im using 64 bit if that complicates things any
Yep 250's
beautiful!
cool.  ok what are the block devices/
i might be able to help.  i'm using a raid0 root right now
i also have a /home raid0 ;)
i love the performance so far
i'm using RAID0(md0): /, ext3, 80G; RAID0(md1): /home, xfs, 180G
ah so what does raid0 have to do with that?  i dont completely understand
ah ok.  wait is this SW raid or HD raid?
warning: i am insanely biased towards SW raid.
in a good way, that is.  SW raid is so much better
so what's your question?
nforce raid isnt supported in linux, to my knowledge.  slower than SW raid too
okay have you already installed and you would like to do this?  or do you want to do this during the install phase?
you dont care about ANY of the data on these partitions you want to stripe, right at the moment, correct?  it will be wiped when the array is created
well if it makes you feel better you can only do it during-install with the Alternate CD
alright so you know the block devices of these two disks right?  250gb each disks?
nope
please prefix your messages with my name so it highlights
type xtk and press tab
beautiful
ok im in /dev in the file browser i kno i kno spoonfeeding :S but umm where would i look for this
oh probably not that.  goto a terminal and type 'sudo fdisk -l'
this is the first time attempting this in ubuntu so pls bear with :)
ah okay
yeah browsing the /dev folder isnt really common practice and it's not gonna help so close that one
you know the terminal?
oh yeah
yeah im fairly well versed with everything else its just raid im totally noob at
ill ask if it doesent make sense to me
ok.  type 'sudo fdisk -l' in the terminal.  i need to know the block devices of the hard disks you want to stripe
a block device is a filename that starts with /dev/  this is a HW address i need
and the other?
Disk /dev/sdc: 250.0 GB, 250059350016 bytes
okay so you're positive it's /dev/sdb and /dev/sdc
cuz the data will be nuked from orbit ;P
thats beautiful my friend will just have to not know that i restarted the whole transfere process lol :P
ok unmount both now
'sudo umount /dev/sdb1' then 'sudo umount /dev/sdc1'
its saying device busy for sudo umount /dev/sdb1
how would i force unmount
eh it usually doesnt work anyway.  close whatever is using sdb1
awwh friggin poop its /home/ :S
lokl
yeah i was in the same situation
*me breathes as he gathers the patience to describe*
oh man thanks for bearing with me here :P you have no idea how much stress this has relieved
ok well you're going to have to do this.
type 'gksu gedit /etc/fstab'
ok im with ya
you want what's in your /home to be preserved?
i can do that
well somewhat ill delete the huge folder i just dropped so its only a few megs but yea
somewhat
'sudo mkdir -p /home_backup && sudo cp -av /home/ /home_backup/'
delete the huge file before you do that
can i live with out this info
without what info?
/home
yea but don't ... trust me
and still be able to chat n all that
let's just try this itll save you so much time
ok ill see kus i just tried copying my data back to /home from buddys drive so it didnt delete properly for some reason
hm one moment
wait nvm
did you take the /home line out of fstab?
i forgot to emty my damn trash 1 min
you hadnt covered that yet
type 'gksu gedit /etc/fstab'
and remove the line containing /home from fstab
ok fstab file is open
# /dev/sda1
place a # before the UUID
that will comment it out
ok save
ok saved
alright now one sec
sudo mkdir -p /home2
sudo mkdir -p /home_backup/ && sudo cp -av /home/ /home_backup/
okay good.  we are going to make /home2
beautiful
got /home2 made?
sorry yeah it is
ok now 'sudo mkdir /home2/tempuser'
yeah thats done now
now 'sudo adduser tempuser --home=/home/tempuser'
oops
oops! hold on
OHHH dont say oops now
lol it's ok
press Ctrl C if you're still going thru the prompts
yes this will be a temporary user.  remember whatever PW you use.  but press Ctrl C now because we made a mistake in the ocmmand.
is Ctrl C not doing anything or sometihng
ctrl c is unresponsive
ok
just go thru the prompts then
we will delete the user after
i could probably just close the terminal window
no just go thru the prompts
risk of corruption is too great otherwise
done
ok now type 'sudo deluser tempuser'
ok were good
ok careful this time
now 'sudo adduser tempuser --home=/home2/tempuser'
that's home2 not home in the //
remember the PW you type
of course ;)
done
ok now 'sudo chown tempuser:tempuser /home2/tempuser'
done
reboot now and login as tempuser instead.  then come back here in xchat.  your /home will have been gone at this point.  we are using an alternate home dir for our temporary user meanwhile.
wait
one sec
k
'sudo adduser tempuser admins'
do this so tempuser will have sudo privileges
and let me check one last thing
yeah no kidding eh that would prolly be good to remember ;)
it is 'admin' not 'admins'
'sudo adduser tempuser admin'
ok he should be in admin if everything went right
ok 1 min
ok yeah its done
ok now reboot.
user tempuser at gdm login
now to re.. beautiful ill be back
i hope this will work.  if it doesnt you might be in a worse state lol.
in case of a worse state use the livecd
err
oh my
hold on again haha
famous last words :\
believe me at this point im really hesitant to reboot lol
'sudo chown tempuser:tempuser /home2/tempuser'
i promise that is the last one...
you may have already typed that i cant remember.  if you did just type it again for the sake of ..everything
hey im not concerned
as long as its just making sure id rather measure twice cut once
yup
now to reboot than...?
yeah
brb
is that a good sign you're here already?
yes yes it is
to tell you the truth i had never done that procedure before..phew
okay
its ok my hands are sweating but were ok!
now make sure /home is empty.  'ls /home'
yes home is empty
ok good
now let's just destroy that /home it's backed up anyway right?
exorctly!
tempuser will stick with you throughout this.  he is your lifeguard
apologies for the simpsons flashback (exorctly)
'sudo apt-get install gparted'
is there much of a diff between apt-get and aptitude ?
no
ok thats kewl ive just been using aptitude kus i dont have to reach for the hyphen :P
we'll have to hurry along as it's my bedtime soon :P
thats kewl gparted is on its way if not done
actually done now!
after gparted installs, 'gksu gparted'

ok.  'gksu gparted' now go to disk /dev/sdb.  on /dev/sdb1 you will press DELETE.  then it will say unallocated.  you will then press CREATE PARTITION in that space, and as the file system choose UNSPECIFIED or UNFORMATTED
its up
done
ok now do the exact same for /dev/sdc1
done
press apply
after applying do not close gparted yet
k its still up
after the Apply is done, you should have two unformatted partitions.  right click on each and click Manage Flags.  enable RAID on both.
this step doesn't actually do anything, it's just for convenience.
and apply those flags
kay
now that that is done, exit gparted
where 2 next?
'sudo mdadm --create --verbose /dev/md0 --level=0 --raid-devices=2 /dev/sdb1 /dev/sdc1'
madm not found, should i apt-get it ??
yeah
installing allready past proompts
well let me know when mdadm--create ... succeeds
succeeded
sudo sh -c 'mdadm --detail --scan >> /etc/mdadm/mdadm.conf'
ok jsut brought me back to ~$
when that completes please pastebin the contents of /etc/mdadm/mdadm.conf
nothing seems to have happened
what do you mean
i need the contents of /etc/mdadm/mdadm.conf :O
it's ok the command above wont do anything..wont appear to
let's go we've almost got this
pastebins not likin me today
darn well post the last line of that file if you would
paste the last line here
is that a duplicate?
gksu gedit /etc/mdadm/mdadm.conf
remove the last, no duplicate
saved
ok now run 'sudo update-initramfs -k `uname -r` -u'
what was the name of your old home user account?  the original account on your PC?
chamunks
alright.  update initramfs done?
yes
now type 'blkid'.  find the one that corresponds to md0
it should say something like this /dev/md0: UUID='6e4589e5-eee7-42fe-8291-22b86764cb8a' SEC_TYPE='ext2' TYPE='ext3'
does it?
oh wait it might not yet.  hold on.  we need to do sometihng else before that.
yeah not yet
btw you can't use gparted to manage this raid partition anymore
im just a smidgen stressed sorry if i pull a few boob moments
'sudo mkfs.ext3 /dev/md0'
this will create an ext3 filesystem on the raid0 partition
really? that kinda smells i like some gui's
i dont think you're going to have to manage it ever anyway
appears to be almost done
ok /dev/md0 is your raid0 ext3 partition.  so now we have to make that /home again.  type 'gksu gedit /etc/fstab'
just about there
uncomment what i did before and edit it some right?
leave what you did before.  dont touch that line
kay
insert an entry like this (spacing doesnt really matter, align it if you want but im kinda in a hurry): '/dev/md0   /home  ext3   defaults   0   0'
i dont really care that much i basicalyl just copied what u wrote if thats kewl
save the file.  then type 'sudo mount -a' in the terminal.  alright it probably mounted fine.  let's copy over old files.  'sudo cp -av /home_backup/* /home/'
it put everything in lost and found for some reason
huh?
/home/lost and found
something like that jazz
um that's weird
well there is a lost+found directory.  that doesnt mean anything else created it.  it's supposed to be there you dont have to worry about that
so have you typed the cp command?
well it says the copy went through but it copied it all to lost+found
weird
sudo cp -av /home_backup/* /home/    exactly as you sent that
type 'gksu nautilus'
and just drag n drop it?
well get it out of lost+found i guess
ok nevermind i refreshed like a min later and its good
okay so the structure should be like so: /home_backup/chamunks/HERE_ARE_MY_FILES
er /home/chamunks/HERE_ARE_MY_FILES too
yep so how would i re enable chamunks user or is that good as is?
now go to the terminal again
ok
let's make sure you own that folder.  'sudo chown -R chamunks:chamunks /home/chamunks'
after that you reboot, login as chamunks, and your /home will be on raid0.  copy his files to anywhere in your home folder and they will be on the raid0.
if all goes well, that is.
ok nevermind it just copied it all /home/home/chamunks it is now
huh?
well it needs to be /home/chamunks/ to work properly.  move it accordingly
thats the way it is now lol yep ok wil do ;)
after that type the chown command.  then reboot.  if you have problems you have to use tempuser.  otherwise you should login as chamunkns
and holy-crap-i-need-sleep so im' gonna have to take off right now.
beautiful thanks your a life saver!!!
night!
even if chamunks login doesnt work , /dev/md0 is your raid device, moutn it somehow if it's not mounted to /home or whatever, but you should be set...
k cya.

devede takes in a media file and outputs a DVD compatible file basically?
yep it wraps it up rather nicely but this second rip box doesent have the hard drive space to do the conversion locally so im hoping to use the nfs mount as the destination aswell as the source
ah i suppose you could do that
i dont relaly remember how to seutp nfs, and i dont have the ambition to walk you through SMB tonight :P
although i must say smb would be a good choice.  between linux and linux thouhg?
I cant say it would be super speedy but it will work
